an4.76:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā at the time of his final extinguishment.
an4.76:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
an4.76:2.1: “Perhaps even a single mendicant has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice. So ask, mendicants! Don’t regret it later, thinking:
an4.76:2.2: ‘We were in the Teacher’s presence and we weren’t able to ask the Buddha a question.’”
an4.76:2.3: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.
an4.76:3.1: For a second time the Buddha addressed the mendicants: …
an4.76:3.4: For a second time, the mendicants kept silent.
an4.76:4.1: For a third time the Buddha addressed the mendicants: …
an4.76:4.4: For a third time, the mendicants kept silent.
an4.76:5.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
an4.76:5.2: “Mendicants, perhaps you don’t ask out of respect for the Teacher. So let a friend tell a friend.”
an4.76:5.3: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.
an4.76:5.4: Then Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
an4.76:5.6: I am quite confident that there’s not even a single mendicant in this Saṅgha who has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice.”
an4.76:6.1: “Ānanda, you speak from faith. But the Realized One knows that there’s not even a single mendicant in this Saṅgha who has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice.
an4.76:6.2: Even the last of these five hundred mendicants is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
